p.s: Dan Holzman: Please throw out the beanbag chairs.

text.s: Barry Friedman: There are all kinds of high-tech chairs here today, but this is really, I think, when it reached its peak as far as ergonomics, comfort, design, flexibility ...

p.s: DH: Now obviously, this is not something we do on our regular show; it's something we just kind of learned for this, so we're going to try.
But can we have some inspirational music for the beanbag chairs?
BF: Nice show, Daniel, nice show.

text.s: DH: Thank you.
BF: You know, sometimes when people do those, they go all the way down.

p.s: (Laughter) That's the kind of extra effort that's gotten us where we are today ...

text.s: DH: All right, let's show them something special.
BF: ... without a MacArthur grant.

p.s: You know, all kinds of different ...
TED is about invention, let's be honest.

text.s: BF: Last night, Michael Moschen showed some juggling props he has invented and working on.
Right now, Dan's going to show something he actually invented.
DH: A type of juggling I actually invented, right after I saw another juggler do it.

p.s: (Laughter) DH: And this is a small excerpt from a longer piece.
(Laughter) (Applause) Folks, this is shaker cup juggling.
It's not a showstopper but it certainly slows it down.

text.s: (Applause) I'm now pushing my luck: I'm skipping right to six cups.

p.s: In order to do six cups, I must have perfect control over three with my right hand.
(Drum roll) BF: Also three with his left.

text.s: DH: Perfect.

p.s: Should I do it on the first try or should I miss once on purpose?
DH: How about if I try first and then decide?

text.s: (Laughter) (Applause) DH: He's looking at me.

p.s: BF: That's all right, he does that.
BF: You know, over the years, every year at the conference, it's kind of become a tradition for us to do something dangerous with Richard.
And we've always done something with the bullwhips in our act.
It's funny, for years I did it with Daniel holding balloons.

text.s: And then we thought, "How stupid."
DH: Excuse me, could we work on the design of the microphone?
BF: I think that's the next session.
DH: Next session?

p.s: And so we've actually found a way to incorporate Richard in this.

text.s: He actually assumes more of the danger in this.

p.s: Richard, please stand in front of me.

text.s: Richard Wurman: Can I say something?
BF: Sure.
RW: In all past years I've rehearsed with them, the things that have happened to me -- I have no idea what's going to happen and that's the truth.
DH: All right, please stand here in front ...

p.s: Put your hands out like this, please.

text.s: (Laughter) BF: No, come stay up with him.
Dan used to actually hold them but now he's got you for protection.
(Laughter) DH: Wow, you've been working out.
BF: No, shut up!

p.s: (Laughter) Having a little bit of Richard time.

text.s: OK, here we go.
Have him hold your wrist so I can ...

p.s: DH: Please hold my wrist, will you.
BF: Yeah, hold this a minute.

text.s: There you go.
(Laughter) OK.
OK, hold on.
RW: Hmmm.
(Laughter) DH: First one.
BF: All those mid-year phone calls are coming back to me now, Richard.

p.s: (Laughter) DH: So Richard, what were we on the list?

text.s: (Laughter) What happened there?
BF: I think we were just outside.

p.s: RW: Do you want me to hold you or not?
DH: Don't hold me that hard.
BF: Here we go, I'm taking it.
(Balloon pops) (Applause) DH: One more, one more.

text.s: BF: We've got one more we're going to do.
RW: Do I get to hold them?
BF: You don't want to hold these, trust me.
DH: Could you spread your legs a little bit?

p.s: (Laughter) BF: Gloria, you want to do it?
Man, I don't want to get too close.

text.s: (Laughter) Could you just push that?

p.s: I always wanted to try that.

text.s: (Laughter) DH: Let's jump this way, though.
Now, we risked Richard's life, it's only fair we risk our own lives.
So to do that, I will juggle these three razor-sharp sickles.
And if that wasn't enough, and judging by your response, it's not ...

p.s: BF: Hoping for a little more build.

text.s: BF: I'm going to run up behind him.
DH: Leap over my shoulder.
BF: Up and over his shoulders.
DH: Grab the blades in mid-air, land right there in a pool of blood ...
BF: Incredible, you say?
DH: Why bother, you say?
BF: Here we go.
DH: Just do it juggler boys, you say?
BF: This guy, this guy invented air.
DH: I think so, that's right.
Even the pencil.
BF: He invented the pencil.
DH: All right, we'll do this trick, but please remember it took us over 10 years to perfect.
BF: Ten years to perfect, which you're about to see.
DH: It's not that difficult, we just don't like to practice that much.
Actually, we will take a second to prove -- this could be fake -- that the blades are indeed razor-sharp.
DH: Will someone please throw a small farm animal up onto the stage?
(Laughter) Or a virgin for a sacrifice?
BF: Anything?

p.s: (Laughter) BF: No, she's got ... farm animal.

text.s: DH: Do you have a small farm animal?

p.s: Just trying to play the odds.

text.s: BF: Over the top, over the top.
BF: Yeah, it's all right.

p.s: DH: Do you feel everything's OK?

text.s: BF: Yeah, a little sketchy.
DH: Everything up here's OK?
BF: Yeah.
DH: Then here we go.

p.s: Could you point that a little more directly into my eyeballs?
(Laughter) I can still see a little.

text.s: DH: And turn up the intensity; we're still pink in the middle.

p.s: It's too much of a visual.

text.s: The design of the body is a whole different thing.

p.s: DH: May we have our jumping music please?
(Silence) May we have it a bit louder?

text.s: BF: We're going on.
DH: All right, we'll try again.

p.s: DH: All right, here we go.
BF: I thought I had the hard part.

text.s: DH: Whenever you're ready.
BF: There we go!
(Applause) Wow, wow, OK, stop.

p.s: (Laughter) I think that's uncomfortable for everyone.

text.s: DH: The French judge ...
BF: One more quick thing.
DH: The French judge gives it a 5.2.
(Laughter) BF: Well, you know ...
DH: Tell them about our bio and stuff.

p.s: In our bio, some of you may have read that we've won two world juggling championships.

text.s: And believe it or not, you don't win juggling champions for doing things with bullwhips or shaker cups.
We're going to show you right now an excerpt from a routine that we used to wipe out the other juggling team competition.
DH: That's right.
BF: Good.
DH: I know what you're thinking: other juggling teams must really suck.
(Laughter) BF: Juggling's got a bad rap.
DH: But wait, Barry, there's still one more club lying there by my foot.
And look, it has a twin!

p.s: (Laughter) DH: There's still one more by my foot.

text.s: What do you want me to do with it?

p.s: BF: Richard you tell him, it's your last year.
(Laughter) DH: That's a pretty good setup, Richard.
BF: Yeah, it's a good setup.
DH: You can't get any better than that.
What I will do: I will use my panther-like reflexes.

text.s: BF: Nice.
DH: I got that -- to reach down and grab that club in my grip of steel.
BF: Nice.
BF: It's progress, that's the thing.
Oh wait, it's on your side, Barry.
And it's awfully windy over there.

p.s: You wouldn't think it would affect half the stage, but it is.

text.s: Watch this: what I'm going to do is slide the seventh one onto my foot.
Oh, look how it lies there.
Oh, Barry, is there nothing you can't do?
Too much Olympics.

p.s: BF: From my foot, I'll attempt to kick the seventh club.

text.s: What gem of knowledge?
What pearl of wisdom?
Do you want to buy a vowel, Barry?
Is that your final answer?

p.s: You have to turn off the TV from time to time.

text.s: DH: I do, I do.
BF: From my foot, the kick up in the seven.
DH: We will juggle seven.
BF: Yes.
DH: Whenever you're ready there, big guy.
Put your tongue away, Barry.
BF: Oh, oh, whoa.
Because now, to make this twice as difficult, we'll juggle the seven clubs back ...
BF: Seven-club juggling.
DH: ... to back.
BF: Thank you, that's it.
BF: Thank you guys!
DH: Thank you very much!
